title: Turkey summons U.S. ambassador over House resolutions on Armenian genocide, sanctions | CBC News
text:
Turkey's foreign ministry said it summoned U.S. Ambassador David Satterfield over two resolutions passed by the U.S. House of Representatives.

The Turkish ministry said in a statement early Wednesday that it rejects the nonbinding House resolution to recognize the century-old mass killings of Armenians by Ottoman Turks as genocide. The bill passed 405-11.

Canada, along with dozens of other countries as well as a United Nations commission, the European Parliament and the Vatican have formally recognized the killings as genocide

In another statement, the ministry said it condemned a bipartisan bill to sanction senior Turkish officials and its army for Turkey's incursion into northeastern Syria, which passed 403-16.

Both bills, which were passed Tuesday, are a sign of further deterioration in U.S.-Turkish relations, which have been strained over multiple issues, especially U.S. support for Syrian Kurdish fighters considered terrorists by Ankara.

U.S. lawmakers have been critical of Ankara's operation against Kurdish forces along the Turkish-Syrian border.
